sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: This document is intended to provide information on the Java interface to the InterMine Query. The IQL document provides a reasonable background to the structure of the interface, since IQL maps fairly directly onto the Java interface. In fact, by far the easiest method of creating a Java InterMine Query object is to use the following constructor:

However, in a Java program, one will occasionally require more flexibility - the Java interface is a more direct method of inserting parameters into the Query, rather than converting them into text and expecting the parser to convert back.

itemizedlist.listitem: The Java Query object has a From list (which is actually a Set), which can contain FromElement objects (which can be QueryClass or Query objects).
The object has a Select list, which can contain any QueryNode object, which include QueryClass, QueryExpression, QueryField, QueryFunction, and QueryValue.
The object has an Order By list, which can contain any QueryNode.
The object has a Group By list (which is actually a Set), which can contain QueryNode objects. However, it does not make sense to include QueryValue objects directly, or QueryFunction objects at all.
The object has a reference to a single Constraint object, but multiple constraints can be included by encapsulating them in a ConstraintSet object.

sect1.title: API Javadoc
sect1.para: The most exhaustive source of information on the Java InterMine Query interface is in the API Javadoc. The InterMine Query is implemented in the org.intermine.objectstore.query package.

sect1.title: An Example
sect1.para: This is an example of how one would build a Java InterMine Query object to represent the IQL query:
sect1.programlisting: SELECT a.field1, a.field2 FROM a WHERE a.field3 = 'Hello';
sect1.para: The Query is built up in stages.
